• Your Cauldron (0)

    Introducing

    George's Marvellous Medicine

    The economy is feeling a bit fragile. And with his last budget before the General Election, George is trying to brew a concoction he hopes could nurse the country back to good health.

    But how to do it? He’s got a cabinet of ideas, but isn’t sure which ingredients are needed to make the perfect recovery. Can you help him?

    Cut International Aid

    Cutting the tiny amount we use to help the lives of the world’s poorest people doesn’t makesense - especially as it takes up less than 1% of the current budget!

    Retirement Age

    When planning to increase the retirement age early, it could hit the poorer, older people affected without enough time to plan for their financial futures - that can’t be good for the country’s economic health!

    Scrap Trident

    A life-saving injection of nearly £100bn from scrapping Trident could pay for the annual budget of NHS England.

    Living Wage

    As pay has flatlined, proposals for a Living Wage could raise a significant amount of money - proving that work will once again be the surest way out of poverty.

    Increasing Tax Threshold

    Raising the threshold on taxes will lose the Treasury £1.5bn. A prescription for disaster!

    Keeping Britain's Houses Warm

    Insulating homes could help millions out of fuel poverty - just the tonic!

    Robin Hood Tax

    A tiny tax on bank financial transactions that could raise £20bn every year! George has opposed a European Robin Hood Tax in the past, but will he swallow his pride (and the medicine).

    Cancel Subsidies to Banks

    Did you know that despite being bailed out for billions by the public, the banks still receive a government subsidy of over £37 billion. No wonder they’re in rude health!

    Benefits Cap

    George has said he’ll cut the safety net for Britain’s poorest families - the majority of whom are in work - from £26,000 to £23,000 would raise a fraction of what a tax on the wealthiest in society could. Perhaps not the remedy needed?

    Clamping Down on Tax Avoidance

    Just imagine: £85 billion every year for our frontline services. Corporations paying their fair share - just what the doctor ordered!

    You need to select at least three policies.

    A Bitter Pill to Swallow

    Prescription: Good!

    Prescription: Good George has found a marvellous medicine! Although he’s finding it a bitter pill to swallow, he knows it’s good for him and the country.

    Prescription: Bad!

    The country’s not looking so great...George on the other hand couldn’t be better! “A spoonful of austerity keeps everybody down...”
